So glad they finally got actual Spaniards to voice the villagers this time. The Latin American accents and expressions on the original were extremely grating from any random Spaniard player's point of view - not due to anything related to racism at all, but because they were utterly immersion-breaking. I'm currently playing the game again on Quest because being in VR turns it into a completely new experience and the only way I'm finding to keep the suspension of disbelief going is to pretend I missed some secret room containing a file that provides some kind of in-game explanation for how and why this very old village in the backwoods of rural Spain turned out to be, against all statistical odds, solely and exclusively populated by first-generation Latin American immigrants.

i enjoy the games Grand Theft Auto 5 and Red Dead Redemption 2.  The only issue I have with those games is how much they hold your hand.   for instance, when an enemy opens fire on you the character you are with will say 'Get Down!!!"   and there will be a prompt at the bottom of the screen stating, get behind some cover.     I understand why the character you are with will shout Get Down but the text prompt as well is a joke.  that is what I mean when I point out that the games were designed to hold your hand.   I have  played the second Red Dead Redemption  6 times.  I have played Grand Theft Auto 5 about the same number, maybe more.  
When Grand Theft Auto 6 comes out I hope Rockstar Games drops the constant need to tell me what to do.   Maybe you could influence the developers to change it if you agree with my perspective of course.

Is this the plot? (SPOLIERS AHEAD) 
So, Silas bit Caleb who then infected his dad (Chris) and his sister (Callie). Leading Caleb to run away. Silas also left which led to the Hackett family setting up the camera and the safety boxes to catch him in case Silas came back. Since sliver bullets kill they wanted to kill Silas leaving everyone in the family uninfected. However, the idea from Eliza flashback is the Hacketts set fire to the show which essentially let Silas out and it was all their fault that her son was gone. Now, Silas doesn’t resurface til the night before camp started when Max and Laura almost hit him. They get kidnapped by Travis whose protecting his family. By end of summer, Chris has bitten Max, who bit Laura(I think it could have been kaylee but I’m not sure), who bit Ryan so he didn’t die. Yet, who bit Nick is unclear however is most likely that it was Caleb because Ryan saw the white wolf (Silas) by the Cabins last. Nick was bit in the forest closer to the island I think. Kaylee is dead because Laura killed her in hopes she was Chris. Bobby, Papa Hackett and Mama Hackett are also dead due to Brad’s choices (I’m okay with these deaths except for Bobby because he was helping the kids and seemed like he was just scared of getting in trouble for not protecting the family.) Now knowing all that the only Hacketts alive are Travis (not infected) and Caleb (infected) but Eliza think the whole family should die for what they did which is why you get her flashback without the choice. However it’s hard to not feel sympathy for the Hacketts learning the hierarchy of the bites. Also we aren’t even sure if the Hacketts were responsible for the fire of Eliza show. Dylan is missing a hand so he didn’t turn when he got bit but other than that everyone else (Kaitlin,Abigail,Emma,Jacob) should be in one piece. But, we also haven’t seen Jacob since Ryan let him out of the cage. Now there are three infected left (Silas,Caleb,Nick). In thinking there was an infected in a cage in the Hacketts house and Dylan and Kaitlin trapped one under the car. The last one should be by the cabins where the radio station was. Also I think it was smart for Max to stay because he probably would of died and then killing Chris would of been pointless. The final choice has to be picking a side (Hacketts or Eliza)(Save Caleb or Silas).

All in all excited to see how this ends and I’ve been a fan of Brad since back when he played Mirrors Edge haven’t stop watching since.

3:08 not sure how many people actually got this reference. The most dangerous game is a story about a hunter who finds himself trapped on an island. That island is where another hunter who is world renowned lives with his bodyguard. This hunter hunts other people now. His rules are if you survive long enough, you get set free. The story ends with the main character killing the other hunter and taking his place.
What I don't understand is why a kid who couldn't care less about highschool English remembers or knows that story.

Random tidbit of info:

North Kill actually isn’t a weird name for a location in New York. New York’s early days consisted of mostly Dutch folk, especially in the upstate. “Kil/kill” in Dutch means a body of water (most commonly a creek or river) you’ll find a bunch of locations/roads/bodies of water with “kill” in the name.

It's become a cliche in horror movies and games that swerving your car is difficult and often leads to crashes,  but it is not difficult and you shouldn't crash. It's just something you need to practice, get a cone and a open area like a parking lot. There is a method to swerving, what you do is turn your wheel one full turn in one direction then half a turn in the opposite direction then another half a turn in the same direction and finally half a turn in the opposite direction.
Example:
 1 full turn to the left 
 1/2 turn to the right 
 1/2 turn to the right again 
 1/2 turn to the left 
Make sure you start slow and only increase speed as you gain proficiency, also be sure to practice swerving to both the left and the right. These are just some tips to help people practice a skill. I think everybody who drives should know how to do this, because it can potentially save your life or at least your car. Have a great day!

I've been playing the game with my girlfriend for a few nights now. It's a good game, but there are some pretty glaring problems. Like there are plenty of moments where your play is interrupted by a cutscene for the characters to have a conversation. Dialog which should have been happening while you were walking around, but it needs to happen in a cutscene to facilitate the "movie mode" which is just cutscenes. That makes the game a little frustrating and slow. While the first game was a literal game with cinematics on top, this is a prolonged cinematic with some game on top. Movie mode seems to be the preferred and even recommended mode of play for this game because it seems to have been prioritized in the development. Then there's a lot of continuity issues which I'll probably comment on throughout these playthroughs.

You know, this episode started off with the tiresome tropes of the high and mighty girlfriend who can do no wrong and the bumbling boyfriend who botches everything, but that sudden turn to the really impatient and arrogant girlfriend and the helpful but reluctant boyfriend was interesting. I didn't expect that turn at all, and it was a welcome change. If I've learned ANYTHING from this genre of games, it's to not suspect creepy people; everyone is equally stupid and untrustworthy until the very much expected monster pops up. Sure, the cop's clearly suspicious since he had a syringe ready to instantly knock out the girl, but still. He should've done what cops ACTUALLY do and guide them to the motel, rather than give them directions and hope for the best. The Fool card could be applied to all three prior to the creepy old hag narrator/guide.
